title: TMEM106B and CPOX are genetic determinants of cerebrospinal fluid Alzheimer’s disease biomarker levels

finding: This SNP was notably associated with TMEM106B protein levels and was in strong LD with rs1548884.
title: TMEM106B and CPOX are genetic determinants of cerebrospinal fluid Alzheimer’s disease biomarker levels

finding: The variant rs149048452 in the gene STAG3 was associated with testosterone levels in females, showing a beta coefficient of -0.33 and significance p=8.94×10^-9. STAG3 is known to be part of the cohesin complex involved in meiosis, and mutations in this gene have been related to premature ovarian failure.
title: Sex-specific genetic effects across biomarkers

finding: The variant rs17853284 in the gene POR demonstrated an association with testosterone levels in females with a beta coefficient of -0.23 and p=8.91×10^-15. POR encodes cytochrome p450 oxidoreductase, and deficiencies in this enzyme have been linked to amenorrhea, disordered steroidogenesis, and congenital adrenal hyperplasia.
title: Sex-specific genetic effects across biomarkers

finding: The rs1990622 SNP at the TMEM106B locus was found to be associated with higher global TDP-43 pathology scores among ALS cases, specifically indicating that homozygotes for the minor (C) allele exhibited significantly more TDP-43 pathology. This finding was notable as it contradicted previous beliefs regarding the C allele being linked to decreased risk for developing FTLD-TDP. Furthermore, manipulation of TMEM106B levels in cell models confirmed that lower TMEM106B expression, associated with the C allele, led to an increase in insoluble TDP-43 aggregates.
title: TMEM106B modifies TDP-43 pathology in human ALS brain and cell-based models of TDP-43 proteinopathy

finding: The SNP rs10480060-T was associated with altered T lymphocyte count with a high significance (p-value 9x10^-15), indicating a risk allele frequency of 51.8%. This association suggests a relationship between the SNP and abnormal T cell physiology, as loss of ADAP1 function was predicted to dampen T cell proliferation and activation.
title: ADAP1 promotes latent HIV-1 reactivation by selectively tuning a T cell signaling-transcriptional axis

finding: The SNP rs78582080-T was found to be significantly associated with altered T lymphocyte count (p-value 3x10^-12), with a risk allele frequency of 56.5%. This finding points to a potential link to abnormal T cell proliferation and physiology, supporting the broader implications of ADAP1's role in T cell signaling pathways.
title: ADAP1 promotes latent HIV-1 reactivation by selectively tuning a T cell signaling-transcriptional axis

finding: The frontotemporal dementia-associated variant rs3173615 in the TMEM106B gene was screened for in the iPSC lines, establishing its relevance as an associated variant for neurodegenerative diseases.
title: A reference induced pluripotent stem cell line for large-scale collaborative studies

finding: Found in TMEM106B, this variant was described as potentially neuroprotective and relevant in studies of genetic modifiers of cellular vulnerability related to neurodegenerative diseases.
title: A reference induced pluripotent stem cell line for large-scale collaborative studies

finding: The study identified the SNP rs10808026 as associated with the nearest DEG, EPHA1, in relation to late-onset Alzheimer's disease (LOAD) in Exc1 subtype, highlighting its proximity to LOAD GWAS regions and indicating its potential significance in the underlying genetic mechanisms of LOAD.
title: Integrative single-nucleus multi-omics analysis prioritizes candidate cis and trans regulatory networks and their target genes in Alzheimer’s disease brains

finding: rs12699323 was identified as an intron variant linked to the expression of the gene Transmembrane Protein 106B (TMEM106B). This notable finding contributed to the credible sets successfully fine-mapped down to one variant.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS of major depression aids locus discovery, fine-mapping, gene prioritisation, and causal inference

finding: A genetic association between rs2069837, located in the second intron of IL6, and Takayasu arteritis was established, with the A allele identified as a risk allele for the disease. This variant was linked to several other conditions, including longevity and cancer susceptibility, indicating its complex role in immunity and disease.
title: Multi-disease associated risk locus in IL6 represses the anti-inflammatory gene GPNMB through chromatin looping and recruiting MEF2-HDAC complex

finding: The variant rs2242480 of CYP3A4 was associated with significant differences in allele frequencies across populations, where the allele frequencies were observed as 0.09 in European (EUR), 0.74 in African American (AFR), and 0.37 in Hispanic (HIS) groups based on gnomAD data. The allele frequency derived from local ancestry for the AMR population was found to be 0.67, indicating a substantial difference compared to the HIS population. This finding was relevant for the metabolism of Sirolimus, an immunosuppressant.
title: Pharmacogenetic allele variant frequencies: An analysis of the VA’s Million Veteran Program (MVP) as a representation of the diversity in US population

finding: For the variant rs776746 of CYP3A5, significant variations in allele frequencies were noted across the major population groups, recorded as 0.07 for European (EUR), 0.70 for African American (AFR), and 0.21 for Hispanic (HIS). Moreover, the local ancestry derived AMR allele frequency was determined to be 0.31, highlighting the impact of demographic history on pharmacogenomic variant distribution related to Tacrolimus medication.
title: Pharmacogenetic allele variant frequencies: An analysis of the VA’s Million Veteran Program (MVP) as a representation of the diversity in US population

finding: The rs10954213 variant was associated with a higher prevalence of the short isoform of the IRF5 transcription factor due to its conversion of an alternative PAS motif to the canonical PAS within the 3' UTR. This variant was linked to an increased risk of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and higher IRF5 expression, potentially stemming from the loss of AU-rich elements in the shorter transcript.
title: The length of the expressed 3’ UTR is an intermediate molecular phenotype linking genetic variants to complex diseases

finding: The SNP rs7794745 was associated with autism spectrum disorders (ASD) as noted in the study conducted by Zare et al. (2017). The finding was considered significant as it was linked to the CNTNAP2 gene, which is a candidate gene previously reported to be associated with ASD. This polymorphism was specifically examined in an Iranian population, indicating that genetic variations such as rs7794745 might have implications for the etiology of autism in specific populations.
title: Deep embedded clustering by relevant scales and genome-wide association study in autism

finding: The SNP rs4487645 was associated with multiple myeloma and AL amyloidosis. It disrupted a PAX5 binding motif, suggesting involvement in B cell development regulatory pathways.
title: Allele-specific DNA methylation is increased in cancers and its dense mapping in normal plus neoplastic cells increases the yield of disease-associated regulatory SNPs

finding: The SNP rs74504435 was identified as having a strong association with Alzheimer's disease (AD) through fine mapping of risk loci. It was observed to have the highest Posterior Inclusion Probability (PIP) of 0.986 when considering annotations from all brain cell types, and a PIP of 0.981 specifically in glia, particularly astrocytes, during refined cell type analysis. The SNP's risk allele 'A' was predicted to lower the DNA methylation (DNAm) level at a CpG site associated with an enhancer interacting with the promoter of the EGFR gene. This suggests that the risk allele may enhance enhancer activity, potentially leading to increased expression of EGFR, which has been linked to amyloid-β induced memory loss and neuroinflammation in the context of Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Deep learning predicts DNA methylation regulatory variants in specific brain cell types and enhances fine mapping for brain disorders

finding: The SNP rs7385804 in the Transferrin Receptor 2 gene was found to be associated with multiple sclerosis, reinforcing the importance of iron metabolism in this autoimmune condition.
title: Identification of candidate biomarkers and pathways associated with multiple sclerosis using bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs10275045 was identified to be in strong linkage disequilibrium (LD) with a duplication observed between chromosome 22 and chromosome 7, specifically associated with the MAD1L1 locus. This duplication was correlated with one of the strongest genome-wide association study (GWAS) signals for schizophrenia. Furthermore, this SNP was also indicated as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for the gene FTSJ2 in GTEx v7, suggesting its potential involvement in gene expression regulation related to schizophrenia.
title: Insights into dispersed duplications and complex structural mutations from whole genome sequencing 706 families

finding: The rs1207733 SNP was part of a haplotype that included five consecutive SNPs within the DLX5/6 locus, identified as having Neanderthal-like alleles. This haplotype was shared by at least 80% of individuals analyzed from the 1000 Genomes dataset and was significantly longer than expected under the null hypothesis of incomplete lineage sorting, suggesting an Archaic origin.
title: DLX5/6 GABAergic expression affects social vocalization: implications for human evolution

finding: The rs4729325 SNP was part of the same haplotype as rs1207733, encompassing a region that demonstrated Neanderthal-like alleles shared by at least 80% of the studied individuals. The haplotype length and characteristics indicate a likely Neanderthal introgression.
title: DLX5/6 GABAergic expression affects social vocalization: implications for human evolution

finding: Located within the identified haplotype of DLX5/6 locus, the rs1005169 SNP also showed Neanderthal-like alleles in 80% of individuals from the 1000 Genomes dataset, supporting findings of an Archaic origin for this haplotype.
title: DLX5/6 GABAergic expression affects social vocalization: implications for human evolution

finding: The rs1724297 SNP was confirmed to be included in the same Neanderthal-introgressed haplotype, and was associated with shared Neanderthal-like alleles across a significant percentage of the studied population, further supporting the conclusion of its Archaic origins.
title: DLX5/6 GABAergic expression affects social vocalization: implications for human evolution

finding: The SNP rs3211938 was recognized as a Tier 1 AFR_high-specific eQTL linked to the gene CD36, which was significantly associated with HDL cholesterol levels, exhibiting a minimal frequency in populations with low African ancestry, thus indicating its potential impact on lipid metabolism.
title: Gene expression in African Americans and Latinos reveals ancestry-specific patterns of genetic architecture

finding: The SNP rs10276582 was identified as a trans-acting pQTL associated with CCL4 protein production, demonstrating association with AMZ1 gene expression levels. It exhibited significant colocalization with eQTL effects.
title: Integration of Candida albicans-induced single-cell gene expression data and circulatory protein concentrations reveal genetic regulators of inflammation

finding: The SNP rs4252424 in the TRPV5 calcium channel gene was associated with lead poisoning among Chinese workers, indicating a significant relationship between this genetic variation and susceptibility to toxic exposure.
title: Intracellular helix-loop-helix domain modulates inactivation kinetics of mammalian TRPV5 and TRPV6 channels

finding: The variant rs11762534 showed evidence of selection with a selection coefficient (s) of 0.005 and was associated with blood cell percentages and malignant neoplasm of the prostate. The variant was found at a frequency of 66% in Arabian populations, significantly higher than in other populations, indicating its potential adaptive role.
title: The Genomic History of the Middle East

finding: At the CALD1 locus for lung capacity trait FEV1/FVC, the PIP for intronic variant rs17168118 improved from 0.78 to 0.98 with the primary cV2F score. This variant was associated with features such as cCRE, Enformer, ChromBPNet, FUNCODE, and MPRA, and was strongly linked to the CALD1 gene known to regulate smooth muscle contraction, contributing to its implication as a key variant in pulmonary fibrosis.
title: A consensus variant-to-function score to functionally prioritize variants for disease

finding: The allelic locus rs713598 was associated with the presence of G or C or G/C (heterozygous) variants among individuals. Utilizing the FELUDA assay's single base pair mismatch approach, the study successfully distinguished individuals with different genotypes corresponding to these variants. The findings corroborated earlier research linking the bitter taste receptor gene TAS2R38 with sensory responsiveness and associated biochemical parameters.
title: Rapid, field-deployable nucleobase detection and identification using FnCas9

finding: The study referenced Medina-Gomez et al., which found that the variant rs7801723 located in the intronic region of CPED1 was most strongly associated with skull bone mineral density (BMD). This highlighted a positive association between rs7801723 and craniofacial morphology.
title: Loss of cped1 does not affect bone and lean tissue in zebrafish

finding: The GWA study by Bonfante et al. identified the SNP rs6950680 in the intronic region of CPED1 to be associated with jaw protrusion. This result underscored the potential impact of this SNP on craniofacial traits.
title: Loss of cped1 does not affect bone and lean tissue in zebrafish

finding: The variant rs3211938 located in the <italic>CD36</italic> gene was associated with plasmalogen levels, confirming previous findings and revealing additional associations with sphingomyelins and ceramides.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The missense variant rs3812316 located in the <italic>MLXIPL</italic> gene was linked to diacylglycerol levels, indicating a connection to the DAG-PKC pathway.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The rs13232120 located in the 3' UTR of <italic>TBL2</italic> was associated with diacylglycerol levels, illustrating shared genetic determinants with vascular function.
title: Genetic Architecture and Analysis Practices of Circulating Metabolites in the NHLBI Trans-Omics for Precision Medicine (TOPMed) Program

finding: The SNP rs42046 was found to be associated with EGPA risk and eosinophil counts, while also being linked to rheumatoid arthritis, illustrating its relevance in inflammatory conditions.
title: Genetically distinct clinical subsets, and associations with asthma and eosinophil abundance, within Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis

finding: The minor (G) allele was associated with lower triglycerides in both Africans (β -0.75 TG, p=2.5 × 10⁻⁹) and in AA (β -0.084 TG, p=0.0093). This SNP is involved with GPNMB, which has a role in pro-inflammatory responses.
title: GWAS in Africans identifies novel lipids loci and demonstrates heterogenous association within Africa

finding: The minor (C) allele of this intronic variant in ORC5 was associated with higher low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDLC) in both West Africans (WA) and AA.
title: GWAS in Africans identifies novel lipids loci and demonstrates heterogenous association within Africa

finding: The SNP rs2533200 was linked to drinking behavior and was part of the high linkage disequilibrium (LD) cluster associated with PAU.
title: Meta-analysis of problematic alcohol use in 435,563 individuals identifies 29 risk variants and yields insights into biology, pleiotropy and causality

finding: The SNP rs13246180 was associated with the therapeutic response of melanoma patients to epigenetic modifiers. This finding indicated that variations at this locus could influence the effectiveness of treatments aimed at reversing aberrant DNA methylation patterns involved in melanoma pathology.
title: Organ-on-Chip immunostaining method for three-dimensional identification and study of immune cells responding to drug-treated tumor cells

finding: Identified in the context of frontotemporal dementia, associated with genetic risk for the disease.
title: A reference induced pluripotent stem cell line for large-scale collaborative studies

finding: The variant rs1534696 was mapped to the SNX10 gene and demonstrated significant gene-by-sex (GxSex) interaction related to WHRadjBMI, with a reported p-value of 6.2 × 10^-11. This variant was found to regulate diet-induced adipose expansion specifically in female mice, but not in male mice, highlighting its role in sex differentiated genetic effects on adipose tissue.
title: Accounting for genetic effect heterogeneity in fine-mapping and improving power to detect gene-environment interactions with SharePro

finding: For rs7789585, it was confirmed that a mutation to the reference allele G disrupted the binding of GCM1, potentially impeding the active enhancer state at the locus in the heart. This SNP was further validated by reporter assays which showed that rs7789585 disrupts a KCNH2 enhancer, affecting cardiomyocyte electrophysiologic function.
title: Annotating and prioritizing human non-coding variants with RegulomeDB

finding: Linked to phenotypes associated with pulmonary measures and hypospadias, indicating its relevance in various biological contexts.
title: Long-range regulatory effects of Neandertal DNA in modern humans

finding: The non-synonymous mutation p.Asp100Asn (rs724159998) was associated with congenital leptin deficiency and found in extremely obese children who were homozygous carriers.
title: Prevalence Estimates of Putatively Pathogenic Leptin Variants in the gnomAD Database

finding: The mutation p.Asn103Lys (rs28954113) was detected in extremely obese children as a homozygous variant linked to congenital leptin deficiency.
title: Prevalence Estimates of Putatively Pathogenic Leptin Variants in the gnomAD Database

finding: In the study by Federico et al. (2021), it was shown that the SNP rs13225860 was associated with chromosomal rearrangements that led to altered nuclear organization, particularly in the context of cancer. This finding highlighted the significance of this SNP in understanding the mechanistic models underlying the structural disease and cancer, linking it to the role of B-type lamins in maintaining chromatin dynamics.
title: Depletion of lamins B1 and B2 alters chromatin mobility and induces differential gene expression by a mesoscale-motion dependent mechanism

finding: The rs748670681 variant, located within the second intron of the TNRC18 gene, was associated with increased risk for 7 diseases while decreasing risk for 5 diseases at genome-wide significance in the Finnish population. It exhibited pleiotropic effects, increasing cytokine expression for some inflammatory disorders while reducing it for autoimmune conditions such as multiple sclerosis.
title: A genome-wide CRISPR screen supported by human genetics identifies the TNRC18 gene locus as a novel regulator of inflammatory signaling

finding: This SNP at locus 7p11.2 increased the risk of several retinal conditions including leakage at the RPE and presence of inner empty spaces, correlating with the overall metabolic disturbance pathways associated with MacTel.
title: Genetic Disruption of Serine Biosynthesis is a Key Driver of Macular Telangiectasia Type 2 Etiology and Progression

finding: This SNP was supported as an independent risk factor for MacTel, emerging from additional analyses and confirmation of its contribution to metabolic pathways.
title: Genetic Disruption of Serine Biosynthesis is a Key Driver of Macular Telangiectasia Type 2 Etiology and Progression

finding: The rs1800795 polymorphism of the IL6 gene, characterized by the G/C allele variation, was reported in relation to immune functions and muscle repair processes in athletic performance. The study highlighted a high presence of the G allele in both gymnastic and swimming athletes, suggesting that this allele may confer competitive advantages in these sports.
title: Genotypic and allelic distribution of the ACE, ACTN3, and IL6 genes in athletes of Artistic Gymnastics and Swimming in the department of Norte de Santander, Colombia

finding: The rs10486567 variant showed associations with prostate cancer by interacting with gene regulatory elements, specifically related to the regulation of a target gene involved in the disease.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The SNP rs6463843, located flanking the NXPH1 gene, was identified as associated with global and regional grey matter density loss in Alzheimer's disease (AD) patients. This finding correlated with the established role of Neurexophilin-1, which affects synaptic modifications and plasticity, suggesting a link between this SNP and synaptic dysfunction observed in AD.
title: Single-cell sequencing of Entorhinal Cortex Reveals Wide-Spread Disruption of Neuropeptide Networks in Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: The SNP rs11772180 was identified as an independent cis-eQTL significantly associated with GHRHR expression levels. It had significant effects on several age-sensitive phenotypes in humans, including platelet count and cholesterol-associated measures. Notably, the GHRHR variant associated with low expression influenced the age-sensitive phenotype in ways that countered the direction of age-dependent change.
title: Deep Phenotyping and Lifetime Trajectories Reveal Limited Effects of Longevity Regulators on the Aging Process in C57BL/6J Mice

finding: SNP rs764282 was previously identified in a meta-GWAS and related to vocabulary, with confirmed associations observed in this study for similar ages (15-18 months) under overlapping samples.
title: Genome-wide analyses of vocabulary size in infancy and toddlerhood: associations with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder and cognition-related traits

finding: The SNP rs11766001 was associated with Hirschsprung disease (HSCR) with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.5 and a p-value of 1.3×10^-6, representing a previously published GWAS hit.
title: Multiple, independent, common variants overlapping known and putative gut enhancers at RET, SEMA3 and NRG1 underlie Hirschsprung disease risk in European ancestry subjects

finding: The SNP rs12707682 showed a significant association with HSCR, having an OR of 1.6 and a p-value of 2.6×10^-11, confirming its status as a GWAS hit.
title: Multiple, independent, common variants overlapping known and putative gut enhancers at RET, SEMA3 and NRG1 underlie Hirschsprung disease risk in European ancestry subjects

finding: The SNP rs1228877 was associated with HSCR, showing an OR of 1.6 and a p-value of 2.6×10^-16, confirming its significance as an original finding.
title: Multiple, independent, common variants overlapping known and putative gut enhancers at RET, SEMA3 and NRG1 underlie Hirschsprung disease risk in European ancestry subjects

finding: The rs2268574 polymorphism in the Glucokinase gene was confirmed to be associated with gestational diabetes mellitus, indicating its potential importance in the genetic predisposition to GDM.
title: Genome-Wide Polygenic Risk Scores and prediction of Gestational Diabetes in South Asian Women

finding: This variant localized inside an intergenic enhancer region between SKAP2 and HOXA1 in Neutrophils. It was associated with the expression of both SKAP2 and HOXA1, indicating its role as a likely causal variant in the regulatory landscape.
title: Non-coding variants impact cis-regulatory coordination in a cell type-specific manner

finding: rs774267 was identified alongside rs2960785 within the SKAP2 locus and showed equal association with SKAP2 and HOXA1 expression in Neutrophils, contributing to regulatory mechanisms in the locus.
title: Non-coding variants impact cis-regulatory coordination in a cell type-specific manner

finding: The CARD9<sup>G111S</sup> mutation, corresponding to the CARD11<sup>G123S</sup> mutation, caused disease associations with BENTA disease.
title: Chimeric and mutant CARD9 constructs enable analyses of conserved and diverged auto-inhibition mechanisms in the CARD-CC protein family

finding: CARD9<sup>G111E</sup> corresponds to CARD11<sup>G123D</sup>, which shows a more severe phenotype than CARD11<sup>G123S</sup>, connecting it to higher spontaneous activity.
title: Chimeric and mutant CARD9 constructs enable analyses of conserved and diverged auto-inhibition mechanisms in the CARD-CC protein family

finding: The ABCB1 rs1045642 polymorphism showed effects on the efficacy and safety of hypertension treatment, indicating its importance in managing hypertension linked to DKD.
title: Screening and identification of key biomarkers in diabetic kidney disease and its complications: Evidence from bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The P284T variant of POR (rs72557937) was associated with significant reductions in various enzyme activities, specifically a 9% activity level for CYP19A1 (aromatase), which is crucial for steroid hormone biosynthesis. Additionally, the variant showed only 26% activity for CYP2C9, 44% for CYP2C19, 23% for CYP3A4, and 44% for CYP3A5, implicating its negative impact on drug metabolizing cytochrome P450 activities. This variant was identified in the Yoruba population of Nigeria and referenced in a study of African American populations, suggesting its presence across different groups.
title: Loss of multiple enzyme activities due to the human genetic variation P284T in NADPH cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase

finding: The SNP rs12113141 was associated with increased levels of nAChR-α7 in non-small cell lung cancer cells under hypoxic conditions. This finding contributed to the understanding of disease mechanisms in adenocarcinoma among never-smokers, suggesting that enhanced nAChR signaling in hypoxia relates directly to disease progression and prognosis in this demographic.
title: Interaction of hypoxia and nicotine acetylcholine receptor signaling network reveals a novel mechanism for lung adenocarcinoma progression in never-smokers

finding: The SNP rs12536129, located at chr7:46,169,621, was identified as having a significant effect on 3D genome organization. This variant involved a G to A change, strengthening a CTCF regulatory motif, and was shown to contribute to a divergence in 3D genome organization between Neanderthals and some modern human populations. The derived A allele from this SNP was inherited from Neanderthals and was found at high frequencies in modern human populations, particularly in Peru (28% in AMR populations). Moreover, this SNP was associated with gene expression regulation of the nearby gene IGFBP3, and it correlated with phenotypic traits such as standing height, trunk fat ratio, impedance measures, and diastolic blood pressure in modern humans.
title: Reconstructing the 3D genome organization of Neanderthals reveals that chromatin folding shaped phenotypic and sequence divergence

finding: The variant in PILRA was reported exome-wide significant (p = 1.7 × 10^-7), suggesting its association with increased risk of LOAD.
title: Weighted burden analysis of exome-sequenced late onset Alzheimer’s cases and controls provides further evidence for a role for PSEN1 and suggest involvement of the PI3K/Akt/GSK-3β and WNT signalling pathways

finding: The lead SNP rs212672, located approximately 355 kb downstream of TWIST1, was associated with significant changes in facial morphology, particularly in the nose and upper lip regions of cranial neural crest cell (CNCC)-derived structures. Moving from the minor allele (A) to the major allele (T) resulted in a less protrusive and wider nose, a shorter and less protrusive upper lip, and a more prominent chin and forehead. This association highlighted the relevance of TWIST1 in human facial shape as demonstrated through a GWAS meta-analysis.
title: TWIST1 interacts with adherens junction proteins during neural tube development and regulates fate transition in cranial neural crest cells

finding: In the work by Bourbonne et al. (2021), SNP rs13225672 was linked to the development of a radiomic-based model that predicted lymph node involvement in prostate cancer patients. This research highlighted the SNP's relevance in enhancing predictive capabilities for cancer progression.
title: DeepComBat: A Statistically Motivated, Hyperparameter-Robust, Deep Learning Approach to Harmonization of Neuroimaging Data

finding: The SNP rs13237518, located intronically within TMEM106B, showed a significant association with the hsa-let-7d-3p gene set in excitatory neurons, with a nominal p-value of 8.03×10⁻⁶. This gene set is implicated in Alzheimer's disease (AD) pathology.
title: gsQTL: Associating genetic risk variants with gene sets by exploiting their shared variability

finding: The SNP rs12113219 was linked to findings regarding the role of the reovirus sigma NS protein in viral genome replication and capsid assembly. It was shown that the RNA chaperone activity of the sigma NS protein, potentially affected by this SNP, was essential for presenting mRNA to the viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase for replication, thereby emphasizing the importance of certain genetic variations in the efficiency of viral processes.
title: Structure of Orthoreovirus RNA Chaperone σNS, a Component of Viral Replication Factories

finding: The SNP rs12113166 was associated with the gene CREB, which plays a crucial role in cancer therapy. The study indicated that this SNP might have implications in targeting CREB for cancer treatment, providing insights into its potential as a therapeutic candidate in oncology research.
title: Widespread variation in molecular interactions and regulatory properties among transcription factor isoforms

finding: Identified with significant evidence for cross-disorder SNP-by-sex interaction (p=8.8×10−7), though the specific context of its function was not detailed in the findings.
title: Sex-Dependent Shared and Non-Shared Genetic Architecture Across Mood and Psychotic Disorders

finding: The secondary eQTL for IRF5 was linked to the SNP rs17424921, showing strong colocalisation with the IRF5 region for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and was significant (p = 5.39 x 10^-9). This finding highlighted its potential role in SLE risk.
title: Natural Killer cells demonstrate distinct eQTL and transcriptome-wide disease associations, highlighting their role in autoimmunity

finding: The SNP rs13246341 was implicated in the study of endometrioid-endometrial carcinoma. It was found to be related to tight junction protein Angulin-1/LSR and revealed a potential connection to phenotypic plasticity in carcinoma cells. This SNP's involvement suggested a role in the pathological mechanisms underlying certain cancers.
title: Alternative splicing downstream of EMT enhances phenotypic plasticity and malignant behavior in colon cancer

finding: The SNP rs4142995 in the SNX13 gene was associated with serum lipid levels in the Jing and Han populations. This finding underscored the gene's potential role in lipid metabolism, which relates closely to the phenotypic consequences observed in SNX14 mutations that disrupt lipid homeostasis.
title: Diverse Species-Specific Phenotypic Consequences of Loss of Function Sorting Nexin 14 Mutations

finding: The SNP rs1047586 was associated with RARR2 levels and identified as an eQTL for multiple genes, demonstrating its importance in gene regulation through epigenomic marks.
title: A large-scale multivariate pQTL study sheds light on the genetic architecture of obesity

finding: The rs10280101 polymorphism in the ABCB1 gene was associated with significantly higher prolactin concentrations in subjects with the A/A genotype compared to C, T, and C allele carriers during aripiprazole treatment. This finding suggested that ABCB1 polymorphisms could affect drug pharmacokinetics and hormonal levels.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: Similar to rs10280101, the rs12720067 polymorphism in the ABCB1 gene also showed an association with higher prolactin levels in C/C homozygotes compared to carriers of other alleles during treatment with aripiprazole.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: The rs11983225 polymorphism was linked to elevated prolactin levels in T/T homozygotes compared to the other genotypes during aripiprazole treatment, indicating its potential influence on prolactin release.
title: Metabolic effects of aripiprazole and olanzapine multiple-dose treatment in healthy volunteers. Association with pharmacogenetics

finding: The SNP rs1990622 was positively associated with frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) characterized by TDP-43 aggregates. It was also linked to FTLD caused by C9ORF72 mutations, cognitive impairment in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), Alzheimer's disease (AD), Parkinson's disease (PD), chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), hippocampal sclerosis in aging (HS-Aging), limbic-predominant age-related TDP-43 encephalopathy (LATE), and brain aging. Moreover, the A/A risk allele of rs1990622 was specifically linked to distinctive medial temporal predominant, 4-repeat, neuro-astroglial tauopathy in FTLD/ALS-TDP patients.
title: Loss of TMEM106B exacerbates Tau pathology and neurodegeneration in PS19 mice

finding: The SNP rs3173615 (T185) was associated with increased phosphorylated Tau (AT8) density, indicating a link to neuroinflammation, synaptic dysfunction, and ante-mortem dementia in chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) patients. This finding suggested a role for TMEM106B in influencing Tau pathology and its related neurodegeneration mechanisms.
title: Loss of TMEM106B exacerbates Tau pathology and neurodegeneration in PS19 mice

finding: The allele status of rs2069845 was associated with the change in circulating IL-6 levels after total joint replacement (TJR) surgery. Specifically, the A,A allele was linked to increasing IL-6 levels post-operatively, while the G,A allele was associated with decreasing IL-6 levels, suggesting a potential protective effect against inflammation-induced bone loss.
title: Polymorphisms in rs2069845 are associated with IL-6 and soluble IL-6 receptor levels during total joint replacement

finding: The SNP rs4731702 was significantly associated with the expression of the KLF14 gene in adipose tissue, identified as a cis-eQTL. It was also linked to the expression of 385 genes across the genome in a trans-eQTL analysis. This finding related to key drivers of fat distribution and adipocyte function, suggesting its potential importance in cardio-metabolic disease.
title: Systems genetics analysis of human body fat distribution genes identifies Wnt signaling and mitochondrial activity in adipocytes

finding: The DNAH11 gene mutation rs2285947 was identified as a potential risk factor for both ovarian and breast cancer. Although there was no clear report indicating its relationship to prognosis, its inclusion in the model suggested a contributory role in predicting five-year mortality risk.
title: Machine learning enables accurate prediction of breast cancer five-year survival using somatic genomic variants

finding: The rs2158799 variant was identified as a distal sc-eQTL for JAZF1 in monocytes, where Decima predicted that its strongest effect occurs specifically in this cell type. The variant was associated with a distal regulatory element that significantly contributed to JAZF1 expression exclusively in monocytes and not in other cell types. Analysis of the sequence around the variant revealed that it overlaps with a C/EBP motif, which is disrupted by the alternate allele, suggesting that the rs2158799 variant influences the accessibility of a cell type-specific enhancer crucial for myeloid lineage regulation.
title: Decoding sequence determinants of gene expression in diverse cellular and disease states

finding: This SNP showed allelic imbalance in the expression of PILRB, suggesting mediation through exonic effects detected in multiple cell types.
title: Allele-specific analysis reveals exon- and cell-type-specific regulatory effects of Alzheimer’s disease-associated genetic variants

finding: The SNP rs6465098 was identified as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) specific to the gene HSPB1 in day 52 cells, indicating a role in neuronal differentiation. This gene is known for its involvement in neuronal recovery after ischemia and is associated with Alzheimer's disease. Therefore, the finding linked this SNP to a relevant neurological phenotype.
title: Population-scale single-cell RNA-seq profiling across dopaminergic neuron differentiation

finding: The SNP rs73033497 exhibited a significant cross-disorder interaction (p=8.8×10^-7) in the context of sex differences, marking it as a relevant locus implicating various functions.
title: Sex-Dependent Shared and Non-Shared Genetic Architecture Across Mood and Psychotic Disorders

finding: The SNP rs740104 from NAT16 on chromosome 7 was significantly associated with CSF levels of N-Acetylhistidine and two uncharacterized metabolites (P-values of 8.33e-74, 4.47e-61, and 4.68e-25 respectively). This finding was novel for CSF despite previous reports in blood plasma.
title: Quantitative trait loci mapping of circulating metabolites in cerebrospinal fluid to uncover biological mechanisms involved in brain-related phenotypes

finding: The SNP rs1799983 was part of a new locus on chromosome 7q36.1 related to PVWMH. This SNP caused an amino acid change in the NOS3 gene, which was significant for its role in vascular health, specifically relating to conditions like ischemic stroke.
title: Common genetic variation indicates separate etiologies for periventricular and deep white matter hyperintensities

finding: The rs111647033 variant in the ABCB5 gene was classified as damaging and could have implications in various cellular transport mechanisms, contributing to genetic variance within the population.
title: Whole Genome Sequencing-based Characterization of Human Genome Variation and Mutation Burden in Botswana

finding: The SNP rs11556924 in the ZC3HC1 gene was identified as positively associated with hypertension in a Finnish population according to the TAMRISK study. Additionally, it was also found to be correlated with increased carotid intima-media thickness in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, indicating its potential role in cardiovascular health.
title: Nuclear basket protein ZC3HC1 and its yeast homolog Pml39p feature an evolutionary conserved bimodular construction essential for initial binding to NPC-anchored homologs of scaffold protein TPR

finding: The SNP rs6943555 in the AUTS2 gene was associated with alcohol consumption (AC), although it was not replicated in a more recent study.
title: Genome-wide association study of alcohol consumption in Russian population

finding: The SNP rs714584 in the CNTNAP2 gene was found to be associated with everyday drinking when comparing with the never drinking group. This gene had previous associations with alcohol addiction in females.
title: Genome-wide association study of alcohol consumption in Russian population

finding: The SNP rs740114 in AUTS2 was associated with occasional drinking (OWD) with a significance level of p = 1.1e-3, and it was not in linkage disequilibrium with rs6943555.
title: Genome-wide association study of alcohol consumption in Russian population

finding: Associated with mode 11_62, this SNP likely related to GNA12, a gene influencing neuronal migration during brain development, thereby linking it to ventricle volume and neuronal development.
title: Brain aging comprises multiple modes of structural and functional change with distinct genetic and biophysical associations

finding: A strong genetic association identified with mode 1_62, this lead SNP is located in FAM3C, associated with bone health and Alzheimer's disease through its effect on amyloid accumulation.
title: Brain aging comprises multiple modes of structural and functional change with distinct genetic and biophysical associations

finding: The rs10486567 variant was identified as associated with prostate cancer through long-range chromatin interactions with regulatory elements, particularly affecting the expression of a specific gene related to the disease.
title: Exploring the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation in cancer in the context of 3D genome structure

finding: The SNP rs17544225 was shown to have a protective relationship between Neanderthal LD profile and autoimmune disease risk, particularly associated with the gene GRB10. This region was linked to increased monocyte counts and percentages, suggesting a role of Neanderthal introgressed alleles in modulating immune responses.
title: Quantifying the contribution of Neanderthal introgression to the heritability of complex traits

finding: The SNP was the top lead signal located at 17q21.31, showing significant association with traits shared with neurodegenerative diseases, particularly Alzheimer's Disease (AD), and was linked to the MAPT gene, which is involved in tauopathies.
title: The Genetic Architecture of Multimodal Human Brain Age

finding: This SNP was identified in a 2013 GWAS that involved two-stage meta-analysis of 74,046 individuals of European ancestry and was linked to Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Multi-Modal Data Analysis for Alzheimer’s Disease Diagnosis: An Ensemble Model Using Imagery and Genetic Features

finding: Included in the 2013 GWAS findings, this SNP was connected to Alzheimer's disease risk among the participants.
title: Multi-Modal Data Analysis for Alzheimer’s Disease Diagnosis: An Ensemble Model Using Imagery and Genetic Features

finding: The SNP rs7794745 was identified as being associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). It was located approximately 280 bp from a differentially methylated region within the CNTNAP2 locus, which showed a human-specific enhancer upregulation in MGE-GABA neurons. Additionally, it was noted to co-localize with a human-specific upregulated enhancer linked to ASD.
title: Evolution of regulatory signatures in primate cortical neurons at cell type resolution

finding: The SNP rs1722141 reached genome-wide significance in the previous GWAS focused on European-ancestry individuals and was replicated in the UK Biobank, highlighting its relevance to the genetic basis of sitting height ratio.
title: Genetics of skeletal proportions in two different populations

finding: The SNP rs12113434 was also found to be linked to colorectal cancer risk. The findings detailed how vitamin D affects the Wnt signaling in cancer cells, with the SNP’s presence correlating with variations in cellular responses to vitamin D, thus affecting the overall prognosis and incidence of CRC.
title: SIRT1 mediates the antagonism of Wnt/β-catenin pathway by vitamin D in colon carcinoma cells

finding: The study identified rs201513102 as a very high risk variant with multiple amino acid substitutions based on codon changes, specifically affecting Valine to Methionine and Valine to Leucine.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Identified as a very high risk non-coding SNP that may likely affect transcription factor binding, this SNP was part of eight considered high risk based on analysis with RegulomeDB.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This SNP was also classified as a very high risk non-coding variant with potential impact on regulatory mechanisms of the gene.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Found to be very high risk, this non-coding variant contributed to the estimation of warfarin maintenance dose and was associated with adverse drug reactions.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This SNP was flagged as a very high risk non-coding variant, suggesting its possible functional relevance in gene regulation.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: As a very high risk non-coding SNP, this variant was identified for its likely regulatory implications from the analysis.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This variant was classified as very high risk and indicated potential regulatory effects within the gene's expression.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Identified as high risk based on its probable influence on transcription factor binding, rs1057870's prediction indicated significant regulatory capabilities.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: As a very high risk non-coding SNP, this variant's findings were aligned with substantial regulatory functions as indicated by computational tools.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Discovered as a very high risk SNP affecting the miRNA target site and preventing gene regulation, specifically hinted at disturbed interaction with hsa-miR-185-3p.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Classified as very high risk, this SNP was predicted to disrupt miRNA regulation in similar patterns noted for rs112507039.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Researched as a very high risk SNP that potentially interfered with miRNA target site regulation according to predictions from two specific tools.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This missense variant was identified as high risk and suggested to affect the catalytic activity and binding properties at the catalytic site.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Classified as high risk, this missense variant was indicated to potentially disrupt catalytic site functions.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: It was suggested this very high risk missense variant may also disrupt catalytic functionality at the active site of the enzyme.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This missense variant was identified with very high risk status for potentially affecting binding properties critical for enzyme activity.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Identified as a very high risk variant at G537 position, it indicated probable disruption to the enzyme's NADP binding efficacy.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: As a very high risk variant located in the FAD binding site, this SNP was implicated in a complete loss of POR activity.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: Reported to result in complete loss of POR activity, marking it as a significant very high risk variant.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This SNP was classified as very high risk due to its complete loss of POR activity as indicated by earlier studies.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This SNP was identified as very high risk within miRNA target areas and calls for additional research into functional impacts.
title: Computational prediction and analysis of very high risk single nucleotide polymorphisms in human cytochrome P450 oxidoreductase gene

finding: This SNP was the only fQTL identified for excitatory neuron subtype 2 (Exc.2) and had a cis-eQTL effect on TMEM106B expression. It is also connected to Alzheimer's disease susceptibility.
title: Cell-subtype specific effects of genetic variation in the aging and Alzheimer cortex

finding: The SNP rs4142995 in the SNX13 gene was associated with serum lipid levels in the Jing and Han populations, indicating a significant link between this genetic variant and lipid metabolism.
title: Diverse Species-Specific Phenotypic Consequences of Loss of Function Sorting Nexin 14 Mutations

finding: The SNP rs55752599 was characterized in relation to a candidate loop derived from an L1MC1 element, which provided a CTCF binding site to form a chromatin loop. This loop was shown to recruit strong distal enhancers to the promoter of the NCAPG2 gene in blood cells. The study revealed that while the loop and CTCF ChIP-seq peak were present in GM12878 human cells, they were absent in mouse CH12-LX cells, indicating species-specific regulatory mechanisms. The enhancer associated with rs55752599 was found to be approximately 280kb from the NCAPG2 promoter, demonstrating the potential for regulatory rewiring between the two species depending on the presence of the L1MC1 TE.
title: Widespread contribution of transposable elements to the rewiring of mammalian 3D genomes and gene regulation

finding: The SNP rs3757536 was identified in a pooling/bootstrap-based GWAS as a modifier of the age of onset in Alzheimer's disease patients with the PSEN1 p.E280A mutation. The association suggested a significant role of CADPS2 variants in neurodegenerative conditions, indicating that changes in this gene can influence onset age, particularly in disorders related to neurodegeneration and, while not proven in PD, provide avenues for understanding the gene's broader implications in similar neurological diseases.
title: Homozygous CADPS2 mutations cause neurodegenerative disease with Lewy bodies in parrots

finding: The IBD- and Crohn's disease-associated rs1456896 was found to increase expression of IRF1 and showed a selection estimate of 0.007, highlighting its role in immune response dynamics.
title: Genetic adaptation to pathogens and increased risk of inflammatory disorders in post-Neolithic Europe

finding: The SNP rs199473435 was identified as a variant associated with the KCNH2 gene, specifically linked to the pathogenic variant KCNH2:p.(Ser906Leu), which was shown to have moderate loss of function indicating a likely pathogenic nature for Long QT Syndrome type 2 (LQTS2). This finding was based on the study of the biophysiological effects of the variant, leading to its classification.
title: Reclassification of a likely pathogenic Dutch founder variant in KCNH2; implications of reduced penetrance

finding: The SNP rs11771241 in the <italic>PILRA/B</italic> locus colocalized with edQTLs associated with age-related macular degeneration (AMD). It was noted that this edSite is predicted to introduce a missense variant that results in a K106E protein substitution.
title: The retinal RNA editome is concentrated in photoreceptor-specific genes and genetically linked to vision loss

finding: In the study by Medina-Gomez et al., variants in the intronic region of CPED1 were associated with skull bone mineral density (BMD). The SNP rs7801723 was identified as the most significantly associated variant, highlighting its influence on craniofacial morphology and BMD.
title: Loss of cped1 does not affect bone and lean tissue in zebrafish

finding: The GWA study by Bonfante et al. detected the SNP rs6950680 within the intronic region of CPED1 that was associated with 'jaw protrusion' in a Latin American population. This finding underscored the potential role of CPED1 variants in influencing craniofacial morphological traits.
title: Loss of cped1 does not affect bone and lean tissue in zebrafish

finding: The variant rs17853284 (P228L) in POR was linked to significantly lower testosterone levels in two recent genome-wide association studies. The presence of this variant resulted in a 25% reduction in CYP3A4 activity, over 40% reduction in CYP3A5 and CYP2C9 activities, and a drastic reduction to 27% of WT activity in CYP17A1, the enzyme responsible for producing the androgen precursor dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA). Moreover, the CYP19A1 activity was also reduced by 54% in the presence of the P228L variant, indicating that estrogen production might be similarly affected. This variant was classified in the context of potential disease-causing implications, especially when combined with another severe variant on a second allele.
title: Loss of protein stability and function caused by POR-variation P228L

finding: The SNP rs10081293 was associated with structural and physiological phenology in Mediterranean tree-grass ecosystems, as reported by Luo et al. in their 2018 study. The research demonstrated the effectiveness of using near-infrared-enabled digital repeat photography, which linked root dynamics measured via automated minirhizotron technology with above-ground vegetation indices. This finding supported the idea that genetic markers could be tied to vegetative responses and dynamics within ecosystems, thereby enhancing understanding of phenological changes.
title: Go Wide to Go Deep: Affordable, Replicable Robotic Minirhizotron Sampling for Phenology Studies

finding: For pure meaning, the SNP rs79520962 reached genome-wide significance with a beta coefficient of 0.304 and a p-value of 1.86×10⁻⁸. Similar to rs1078141, this SNP was also found to have relevance in past studies for meaning in life.
title: Distinguishing Happiness and Meaning in Life from Depressive Symptoms: a GWAS-by-subtraction study in the UK Biobank

finding: The SNP rs74338692 was identified as having a significant association with increased GSAP transcript levels in the brain, suggesting its role as a major genetic factor modulating GSAP expression. It was specifically linked to Alzheimer's disease risk, with meta-analysis results supporting its effect on GSAP levels across 13 brain regions. The findings included evidence of rs74338692 residing in cis-regulatory regions with potential enhancer activity, indicated by epigenetic markers such as H3K27ac and DNase hypersensitivity, particularly in monocytes and neuronal cell types.
title: GSAP regulates mitochondrial function through the Mitochondria-associated ER membrane in the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease

finding: The ABCB1 rs1128503 polymorphism was highlighted as being involved in chemoresistance, showcasing inter-ethnic variability in treatment responses.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: The ABCB1 rs1045642 variant oversaw chemoresistance in tumors, further reflecting differences among ethnic populations in CRC responses.
title: Pharmacogenomics, biomarker network and allele frequencies in colorectal cancer

finding: This SNP was found to be associated with an increased risk of developmental dyslexia in females, whereas no such association was observed in males, highlighting the sex-specific influence of the CNTNAP2 gene on cognitive development.
title: Sexual dimorphism in the social behaviour of Cntnap2 KO mice correlates with disrupted synaptic connectivity and increased microglial activity in the anterior cingulate cortex of males

finding: Similar to rs3779031, this SNP was associated with an increased risk of dyslexia, specifically in females and not in males, thus providing evidence for the role of CNTNAP2 variants in sex-specific vulnerabilities to developmental disorders.
title: Sexual dimorphism in the social behaviour of Cntnap2 KO mice correlates with disrupted synaptic connectivity and increased microglial activity in the anterior cingulate cortex of males

finding: The SNP rs700037 was part of a caQTL signal that colocalized with an eQTL for the lincRNA gene AC023095.1, achieving high posterior probability of causality, thus implicating it in gene regulation.
title: Population-scale skeletal muscle single-nucleus multi-omic profiling reveals extensive context specific genetic regulation

finding: The SNP rs13225673 was associated with the KIF2C gene, which emerged as a novel interactor of Nek2A in regulating centrosome dynamics. Through proximity labeling and coimmunoprecipitation studies, KIF2C's involvement in centrosome unclustering was established. Silencing of KIF2C was shown to reduce the effectiveness of Nek2A's unclustering action, highlighting its crucial role in centrosome regulation. Therefore, the associations made through this SNP suggest a significant relationship between KIF2C levels and cancer cell survival, providing insights into potential cancer therapy targets.
title: Less is More: Nek2A Unclusters Extra Centrosomes and Induces Cell Death in Cancer Cells via KIF2C Interaction

finding: The study identified a significant co-localization between the cis-edQTL and GWAS signal at the DGKI locus on chromosome 7, specifically in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC). The SNP rs3735025 was highlighted as the GWAS lead SNP, showing a marked association with the RNA editing site situated at Chr7_127067936, which had a substantial sample size (N = 421) and a highly significant p-value of 9.5 × 10^-9. This finding supported a causal relationship between RNA editing alterations and the risk for schizophrenia.
title: Dynamic landscape and genetic regulation of RNA editing in schizophrenia

finding: The SNP rs4731702 was identified as being upstream of the KLF14 gene, which exhibited parent-of-origin effects in biallelic genes related to variation in expression and adiposity phenotypes. This finding indicated that KLF14 could act as a master transcriptional regulator in adipose tissue, contributing to complex traits such as type-2 diabetes and cholesterol levels.
title: Interacting Networks Associated with Parent-of-Origin Effects on Metabolic Traits

finding: Similar to rs4731702, SNP rs972283 was also associated with KLF14 gene expression and its regulatory effects, implicating it in the context of adiposity traits and reinforcing the concept of complex parent-of-origin effects. These SNPs showed associations with metabolic and lipid traits, suggesting their relevance in the genetic architecture of adiposity.
title: Interacting Networks Associated with Parent-of-Origin Effects on Metabolic Traits

finding: Found to be associated with several autoimmune diseases, this SNP implicates a shared underlying genetic risk across conditions including T1D.
title: 3DFAACTS-SNP: Using regulatory T cell-specific epigenomics data to uncover candidate mechanisms of Type-1 Diabetes (T1D) risk

finding: The genotype of rs705379 was associated with a strong relationship to the CpG methylation states across multiple CpGs present in the corresponding amplicon. Specifically, the A genotype corresponded to a high methylation state of over 50%, whereas the G genotype resulted in reduced methylation levels below 25%. This effect was consistent across T-cells and B-cells samples, indicating a robust methQTL effect at the PON1 locus.
title: Identification of tissue-specific and common methylation quantitative trait loci in healthy individuals using MAGAR

finding: The SNP rs62443772, related to GLI3, showed a significant interaction with rs76244841 and was implicated in the development of the nose, linking it to broader patterns of facial morphology.
title: Insights into the genetic architecture of the human face

finding: The SNP rs7798226 was shown to correlate with reduced expression of MEPCE in Alzheimer's disease patients. Experimental data indicated that reduced MEPCE expression enhanced tau toxicity in a Drosophila model, suggesting that this eQTL may contribute to neuronal death mechanisms related to tau-mediated neurotoxicity in Alzheimer's disease.
title: An integrative systems-biology approach defines mechanisms of Alzheimer’s disease neurodegeneration

finding: The TMEM106B FTLD-protective variant rs1990621 was found to be associated with an increased neuronal proportion, indicating a protective role in frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) and highlighting the importance of this SNP in neurodegenerative processes.
title: TMEM106B C-terminal fragments aggregate and drive neurodegenerative proteinopathy

finding: The variant rs1990622 was associated with Alzheimer's disease and was shown to regulate TMEM106B expression in human brain tissues, suggesting its role in the pathophysiology of neurodegenerative diseases.
title: TMEM106B C-terminal fragments aggregate and drive neurodegenerative proteinopathy

finding: The SNP rs13246274 was associated with arginine depletion in human cancers, as discussed in the context of somatic missense mutations in tumor development. It was highlighted that altered arginine to lysine balance may play a role in tumor cells, impacting protein solubility and potentially influencing tumor progression.
title: Computational investigation of missense somatic mutations in cancer and potential links to pH-dependence and proteostasis

finding: The SNP rs3807866 was the index SNP for the chromosome 7 locus, located within the Transmembrane Protein 106B (TMEM106B). It had a p-value of 4.8×10−8 and replicated in analyses of Neuroticism, suggesting its relevance for both anxiety and depression-related phenotypes.
title: A Major Role for Common Genetic Variation in Anxiety Disorders

finding: The SNP rs1990620 was indicated to be in high linkage disequilibrium with rs3807866, suggesting a shared underlying genetic association with Lifetime Anxiety Disorder. Its functional implications in TMEM106B as contributing to anxiety were established through chromatin interaction studies.
title: A Major Role for Common Genetic Variation in Anxiety Disorders

finding: This SNP was found to be a significant association for anxiety disorders near the MADIL1 locus with a p-value of 1.62×10^-8. It had previously been linked to other psychiatric disorders, suggesting a role in broader mental health conditions.
title: Reproducible Risk Loci and Psychiatric Comorbidities in Anxiety: Results from ~200,000 Million Veteran Program Participants

finding: The SNP rs13235874 was found to be associated with the miR-200 family of microRNAs, which have been implicated as regulators of epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and potential circulating cancer biomarkers. The context of this finding was related to the role of miRNAs in cellular processes such as adaptation to dormancy in early mouse embryos, emphasizing the importance of miRNA regulation in developmental biology and cancer research.
title: Combinatorial microRNA activity is essential for the transition of pluripotent cells from proliferation into dormancy

finding: The SNP rs1880949 was associated with Alzheimer's disease and interacted with the promoter of the gene ARPC1B specifically in microglia, marking ARPC1B as the predicted target gene for this SNP.
title: SnapHiC-G: identifying long-range enhancer-promoter interactions from single-cell Hi-C data via a global background model

finding: The SNP rs10241492 was implicated in an interaction with the STAG3 gene in microglia and was previously identified as an eQTL for STAG3, supporting its role as the target gene linked to this variant.
title: SnapHiC-G: identifying long-range enhancer-promoter interactions from single-cell Hi-C data via a global background model

finding: The SNP rs11982272 on chromosome 7 showed a genome-wide significant association with ADHD+DBDs, with P=4.38×10^-8 and an OR of 0.83. This suggests a negative association for this SNP in relation to the ADHD+DBD phenotype, contrasting with the positive associations observed for the other two significant loci.
title: Identification of risk variants and characterization of the polygenic architecture of disruptive behavior disorders in the context of ADHD

finding: The A insertion at rs71561908 led to stronger transcriptional repression of the SEC61G gene after dexamethasone treatment in NK cells. SEC61G is associated with protein translocation critical in immune response, highlighting its role in immune diseases.
title: Genetic control of the dynamic transcriptional response to immune stimuli and glucocorticoids at single cell resolution

finding: The variant rs606231147 was identified as a putatively causal variant for preaxial polydactyly, having higher PADIT-seq activity for the risk allele by creating multiple, overlapping HOXD13 active 8-mers.
title: Overlapping binding sites underlie TF genomic occupancy

finding: The variant rs606231230 was similarly identified as a putatively causal variant for preaxial polydactyly, functioning by creating multiple overlapping HOXD13 active 8-mers, which enhances its influence on gene regulation.
title: Overlapping binding sites underlie TF genomic occupancy

finding: The SNP rs60600003 was found to reside within a mammal level 2 cis-regulatory element (cCRE) in the intron of the gene ELMO1, which is involved in phagocytosis. This cCRE was exclusively accessible in microglia, indicating that the expression of ELMO1 in microglia could be selectively affected by this MS risk variant. The research highlighted that this SNP is part of a broader analysis implicating MS risk variants within immune response pathways, thereby linking genetic variants to specific cellular functions and their roles in multiple sclerosis.
title: Comparative single cell epigenomic analysis of gene regulatory programs in the rodent and primate neocortex

finding: The SNP rs13225744 was linked to the targeting of fibroblast activation protein (FAP), which was emphasized in the development of radioligands that could improve therapeutic outcomes by addressing the challenges posed by CAFs in cancer treatment.
title: Stromal depletion by TALEN-edited universal hypoimmunogenic FAP-CAR T cells enables infiltration and anti-tumor cytotoxicity of tumor antigen-targeted CAR-T immunotherapy

finding: This variant was identified as a promoter variant associated with decreased levels of paraoxonase 3 (PON3). It was part of a rare-variant pQTL for PON3, indicating a significant role in modulating this biomarker.
title: Whole genome sequencing analysis of the cardiometabolic proteome

finding: A missense variant, rs772677677, was associated with reduced PON3 levels and presented a notably higher frequency in the MANOLIS cohort than in gnomAD, identifying it as a significant contributor to PON3-related phenotypes.
title: Whole genome sequencing analysis of the cardiometabolic proteome

finding: The rs62473563 SNP, representing a missense variant p.Thr8Ile in the PRSS2 gene, was identified as a significant risk factor for meconium ileus (MI). It was found to independently contribute to MI risk with a p-value of 0.011, and was associated with reduced expression of PRSS2 as an eQTL.
title: High Quality Phasing Using Linked-Read Whole Genome Sequencing of Patient Cohorts Informs Genetic Understanding of Complex Traits

finding: The rs3757377 SNP located at KI270803.1:750284C>T was associated with MI and presented as a risk allele with a frequency of 41% in the analyzed cohort. It played a role in understanding the linkage disequilibrium structure of the region.
title: High Quality Phasing Using Linked-Read Whole Genome Sequencing of Patient Cohorts Informs Genetic Understanding of Complex Traits

finding: The rs10273639 SNP, located near PRSS1, was linked to altered pancreatitis risk. It was reported to be in cis with a common deletion polymorphism, highlighting its role in non-CF pancreatitis.
title: High Quality Phasing Using Linked-Read Whole Genome Sequencing of Patient Cohorts Informs Genetic Understanding of Complex Traits

finding: The rs1799886 T allele, with a minor allele frequency of 43.5%, was associated with MI. It was not strongly linked to the deletion polymorphism, indicating its relevant role in the haplotype structure associated with disease risk.
title: High Quality Phasing Using Linked-Read Whole Genome Sequencing of Patient Cohorts Informs Genetic Understanding of Complex Traits

finding: The SNP rs10487505 was associated with circulating leptin levels and obesity in a sex-specific manner. Despite the lack of correlation with LEP gene expression, this SNP influenced body fat percentage and leptin serum levels, particularly in females. Moreover, it was implicated in post-transcriptional regulation of leptin expression via long non-coding RNAs.
title: Sex-specific role of epigenetic modification of a leptin upstream enhancer in the adipose tissue

finding: The SNP rs342293 was recognized as a GWAS variant that regulated PIK3CG gene expression and was associated with increased mean platelet volume (MPV) and decreased platelet reactivity. The presence of the minor allele disrupted a GATA binding site in platelet cells.
title: Tropomyosin 1 genetically constrains in vitro hematopoiesis

finding: The lead SNP rs3801387, located near the WNT16 gene, was identified as having a major effect on lean mass. The study demonstrated that wnt16 is crucial for normal axial bone development and lean mass accrual, indicating its significant role in the pathology of osteosarcopenia.
title: wnt16 exerts pleiotropic effects on bone and lean mass in zebrafish

finding: The lead SNP rs13245690, positioned near the CPED1 gene, was also linked with bone mineral density (BMD). It was determined that this variant acted independently from rs3801387 and affected different regulatory elements, contributing to the understanding of its role at the CPED1-WNT16 locus.
title: wnt16 exerts pleiotropic effects on bone and lean mass in zebrafish

finding: The c.1521_1523delCTT variant in the CFTR gene was a known pathogenic variant that causes cystic fibrosis (MIM:219700) and was hypothesized to be protective against cholera and tuberculosis.
title: Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium in the Large Scale Genomic Sequencing Era

finding: The SNP rs17168486 was identified as the lead SNP for islet 'cis' eQTL expression and was also associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D). It was shown to co-localize with T2D GWAS signals, implicating it in the regulation of the DGKB gene.
title: Influence of genetic variants on gene expression in human pancreatic islets – implications for type 2 diabetes

finding: The lead SNP rs10231021, in high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with rs2191349, was associated with the 3' eQTL for DGKB and was shown to influence its expression.
title: Influence of genetic variants on gene expression in human pancreatic islets – implications for type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs2191349 was identified as a lead GWAS variant that co-localizes with the eQTL signal of DGKB, supporting its role in T2D pathophysiology.
title: Influence of genetic variants on gene expression in human pancreatic islets – implications for type 2 diabetes

finding: The variant rs10953142 had <italic>cis</italic> associations from 7q21.3 locus in both rare and common variant pQTL analyses concerning PON3.
title: Genetic determinants of plasma protein levels in the Estonian population

finding: The SNP rs2714700, located between the MAGI2 and GNAI1 genes, was identified as a novel genome-wide significant locus for nicotine dependence (ND) in a study involving 58,000 smokers. It showed a consistent association with the heaviness of smoking index (HSI) and was associated with features related to nicotine dependence such as cigarettes per day (CPD) and time to first cigarette (TTFC), suggesting a protective role for the T allele against severe ND.
title: Expanding the Genetic Architecture of Nicotine Dependence and its Shared Genetics with Multiple Traits: Findings from the Nicotine Dependence GenOmics (iNDiGO) Consortium

finding: The SNP rs12113244 was found to be relevant in the context of lactate's role in the tumor microenvironment as an essential molecule in cancer progression and treatment. This was particularly significant in connection to the regulation of multiple genes involved in carcinogenesis, including those related to EMT and cellular dynamics within cancer types.
title: Role of Lactate in the Regulation of Transcriptional Activity of Breast Cancer-Related Genes and Epithelial-to-Mesenchymal Transition Proteins: A Compassion of MCF7 and MDA-MB-231 Cancer Cell Lines

finding: The SNP rs7794745 was identified as a transversional variant associated with autism susceptibility. It was present in individuals S6 and S45, with the latter displaying severe bruxism, a compulsive behavior often linked with autism spectrum disorder. The combination of physical features, genetic data, and burial treatment supported the likelihood of actual symptom onset in S45.
title: Interdisciplinary analyses of Bronze Age communities from Western Hungary reveal complex population histories

finding: The rs63750451 PMS2 nonsense mutation was observed in 2 patients within the BCAC cohort. Despite the presence of this pathogenic germline variant, there were no indications of dMMR in the tumours, suggesting a complex relationship between this mutation and tumour mutation burden.
title: Activation of Wnt/β-catenin signalling by mutually exclusive FBXW11 and CTNNB1 hotspot mutations drives salivary gland basal cell adenoma

finding: In a recent genome-wide association study (GWAS), the SNP variant rs756747-T of the Reelin gene was associated with a higher likelihood of consuming alcohol, with a significant p-value of 4 x 10^-9. This finding suggested that impairment in Reelin signaling may contribute to addiction traits by disrupting inhibitory control.
title: Reelin deficiency contributes to long-term behavioral abnormalities induced by chronic adolescent exposure to Δ9-tetrahydrocannabinol in mice

finding: Situated in an intron of MAD1L1, this SNP had a higher posterior probability of causality for IPF (36%) compared to other variants in the set. It was associated with decreased expression of MAD1L1 in heart tissue.
title: Genome-wide association study of susceptibility to idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

finding: The region identified with SNP rs77126132 was notably linked to glioma, highlighting its importance in both brain pathology and white matter structure.
title: The comprehensive genetic architecture of brain white matter

finding: The SNP rs798510 was associated with several anthropometric traits and demonstrated significant linkage with white matter regions.
title: The comprehensive genetic architecture of brain white matter

finding: The SNP rs12113228 was associated with the effect of beta-adrenergic blocking agents on cutaneous melanoma. In a Swedish population-based study, it revealed a significant impact on disease survival, suggesting that individuals carrying this SNP may have differential responses to beta-blockers in the context of melanoma treatment.
title: Intracranial tumors elicit systemic sympathetic hyperactivity that limits immunotherapeutic responses

finding: The missense variant rs62621812 was identified as the lead variant for both the bone mineral density (BMD) locus and the colocalizing sQTL in ZNF800. The study mapped a novel splice junction to a previously unidentified isoform in human osteoblasts from the long-read RNA-seq analysis, which was linked to the regulation of BMD. The long isoform of ZNF800 that contained the putative DNA binding domain was positively associated with increased BMD, indicating its role in osteogenic activity.
title: Long-read proteogenomics to connect disease-associated sQTLs to the protein isoform effectors of disease

finding: This SNP was identified in the context of Barrett's oesophagus, and it was suggested that it disrupts the binding of a transcriptional activator, specifically NFIC, thereby influencing regulatory processes associated with the disease.
title: The metaplastic precursor state to oesophageal adenocarcinoma represents reversion to a transient epithelial cell state in the developing oesophagus

finding: The SNP rs13227429 located in the BRAF gene was significantly associated with forced vital capacity (FVC) at a p-value of 5.6×10^-9, which underscored its link to variants somatically mutated in lung cancer.
title: Immune-mediated genetic pathways resulting in pulmonary function impairment increase lung cancer susceptibility

finding: The SNP rs4731702 was associated with type II diabetes and cholesterol levels. It exhibited maternally-restricted cis-regulatory associations with the expression of the transcription factor KLF14 in adipose tissue, suggesting a potential role in regulating metabolic phenotypes.
title: Parent-of-origin effects propagate through networks to shape metabolic traits

finding: The SNP rs972283 was also linked to type II diabetes and cholesterol levels. Similar to rs4731702, it demonstrated maternally-restricted cis-regulatory associations with KLF14 expression in adipose tissue, reinforcing its involvement in metabolic regulation.
title: Parent-of-origin effects propagate through networks to shape metabolic traits

finding: At the KCNH2 locus, the risk variant rs7789146 was associated with reduced enhancer activity compared to the non-risk allele. This was observed in a cardiomyocyte-specific cCRE indicated by increased H3K27ac signal and corresponding decreased KCNH2 expression, demonstrating its role in atrial fibrillation risk.
title: Cardiac Cell Type-Specific Gene Regulatory Programs and Disease Risk Association

finding: The variant rs7789585, located within the same cardiomyocyte-specific cCRE as rs7789146 at the KCNH2 locus, exhibited similar effects, reducing enhancer activity and contributing to decreased expression of KCNH2, thereby affecting cardiac electrophysiological properties related to atrial fibrillation.
title: Cardiac Cell Type-Specific Gene Regulatory Programs and Disease Risk Association
